hit Barrett's Reef but managed to get clear and for most of the morning lay about a quarter

By late afternoon about 50 people had been taken to Wellington Hospital for treatment.
Some of the small craft engaged on rescue operations landed in the Eastbourne area
and casualties from these boats were rushed to Hutt Hospital.
The Picton Ferry Aramwana and the police launch Lady Elizabeth headed the rescue operation,
but as the wind dropped and the seas grew less dangerous, many small craft and even surf boats went out to look for survivors.

She bore a fated name.
Her namesake, the 4.5,000-ton troop ship,
founded some years ago after hitting a reef 300 miles north of Darwin,
but on that occasion there was no loss of life.

How long were you told before you had to abandon ship?
Two minutes.
Two minutes.

We told to go on the starboard side, but that was impossible because it was so slippery and such as list.
Well, you've given any drill before you went over the side? Any lightbird drill?
Was there any chance to give you lightbird drill?
Bodies from the Wahinae have been brought to shore at many points around the harbour.
Bodies have been recovered from the eastern beaches from Pencaro to Eastbourne.
Tonight, the police are continuing the search for other bodies.
The union company's managing director, Mr. F. K. McFarlane,
has expressed his company's sympathy to those bereaved

The search of the harbor for the last of the survivors and for bodies is continuing throughout
the night in the area of the wreck.
